item.title: CS289 Final Project
item.description:
Modelization of single-cell gene expression along a timeline

Report abstract

The explosion of genomic data over the past two decades created a need for new and more performing tools. One type of data in particular, Single-cell RNA Sequencing data, allow for a cell-level detection of biological patterns but technical limitations add lots of noise sources to the data. In particular, some counts are dropped and appear as zeros, even thought the gene is expressed in the cell. Here, we present a new method to detect dropouts in cases of development trajectories. Our various model all improve substantially on random guesses and offer a computationally-efficient way to infer correct gene expression patterns over time. The GitHub containing all our scripts is available online at the following address: https://github.com/HectorRDB/CS289_Final_Project

Spring 2018

Group members: Daniel Amar, Ariane Lozac’hmeur, Hector Roux de Bézieux & Alexandre Vincent

  • The project proposal is available on Overleaf and may be read here.
  • The project report is available on Overleaf and may be read here.

item.title: Ressources for 'omics analysis
item.description:
[THIS IS A DRAFT]

Overview

Recently, a new member joined the Dudoit lab and I had to think on which ressources to point him to so that he could start getting up to speed with on the field. I think that the ressources I recommand fall into 4 broad (and largely overlapping) categories:

  • Biology and techniques
  • How to find, acess and pre-process data (including how to use bio-informatics tools)
  • Statistics
  • How to use all of the above to conduct an analysis (with - of course - a strong emphasis on R tools)

I’ll therefore try to list ressources to help in all subjects. This will be a mix of (scientific) papers, books, package vignette, personal tutorials, video…

If you find any other ressources, feel free to contact me.

Before we begin

Those ressources assume that you have at least a basic knowledge of R, statistics and biology. For R otherwise, I recommand (and I am far from the only one) Garrett Grolemund & Hadley Wickham’s R For Data Science. Any suggestions for biology and statistics introductory guides are weclome.

Biology and techniques

Koen review Central dogma Illumina video Sanger sequencing

Getting your hands on data

A first - and excellent - ressource of good pre-processed data is the recount2 project.

https://www.nature.com/articles/nprot.2012.016 Kallisto

STAR

Link to bash tuto

script for pubmed (diya)

Statistics

Susan’s Holmes Modern Statistics for Modern Biology Dim reduction (link rebecca’s slide with permission or actually build tuto) Clustering (link to book chapter)

https://github.com/jtleek/genomicspapers

Applications to RNA-Seq

https://github.com/jtleek/genomicspapers as well

salens review EDA: Rebecca’s ggplot tutorial (make a new one more bio focused? Maybe based on Dada2). Koen review (bis) Bioconductor workshop

Reproducible research

http://vita.had.co.nz/papers/tidy-data.pdf R package Github advanced R Cargo statistics blog post

item.title: STAT 215A: Labs
item.description:
STAT 215A Statistical Models: Theory and Application

I took this class in the Fall 2017, with Bin Yu and Rebecca Barter. For the purpose of this class, we studied 3 datasets across 4 labs. The grading was partly peer-reviewed based so my github for this class contains works from other students that I cannot share. However, the lab reports and code files are below:

Lab 1: Redwood trees Lab 2: Linguistic Survey Lab 3: Linguistic Survey Stability Lab 4: Cloud detection
Report Lab1 Lab2 Lab3 Lab4
Code Lab1 Lab2 Lab3 Lab4

Likewise, for the final report, the project report and code are accessible.

I also highly recommand to go and visit Rebecca Barter’s website for great tutorials.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Welcome to Slides

Academic

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = \;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation
